docs.abstract: Natalie Angier article on why men die off in greater numbers than women at every stage of life, even though they are less likely to be fat, exercise more and have less depression and fewer chronic diseases; points to male's impressive tendency to self-destruct, behind the wheel, by homicide, or through alcoholism, drug addiction and suicide; risk-taking behaviors and myth of 'masculinity' that inhibits emotional coping skills discussed (M)

headline.main: Why Men Don't Last: Self-Destruction as a Way of Life

docs.lead_paragraph: MY father had great habits. Long before ficus trees met weight machines, he was a dogged exerciser. He did push-ups and isometrics. He climbed rocks. He went for long, vigorous walks. He ate sparingly and avoided sweets and grease. He took such good care of his teeth that they looked fake. My father had terrible habits. He was chronically angry. He threw things around the house and broke them. He didn't drink often, but when he did, he turned more violent than usual. He didn't go to doctors, even when we begged him to. He let a big, ugly mole on his back grow bigger and bigger, and so he died of malignant melanoma, a curable cancer, at 51.

docs.abstract: Comment on American male's views on fashion, and dawning awareness that clothes can make the man, or at least provide some camouflage; photo of George Wendt, Joe Morton and Judd Hirsch on set of play Art (S)

headline.main: A Talented Tailor Can Cut a Fellow a Lot of Slack

docs.lead_paragraph: ''YOU'VE gained weight,'' Marc (Judd Hirsch) tells his crony Yvan (George Wendt) pointedly and more than once in the Broadway production of ''Art.'' But if Yvan is wounded, it scarcely shows, Marc's cutting remark making nary a dent in Yvan's self-esteem. In some ways Yvan is a prosperous Everyman, sure of himself, on his good days, and just as sure of his magnetism. The source of his untrammeled confidence: not a tapering waist or steely backside, but his power, his vigor -- and not least, of course, his wardrobe.

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte comment on typical male reluctance to seek out medical attention, and his own necessary self-education as assertive health consumer (M)

headline.main: Don't Take Your Medicine Like a Man; As Patients, Men Are Impatient, or Uneasy, or Both. They Need to Get a Grip, Like Women.

docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTORS once loved me, or would have if I had gone to them more often. Fix me quick, sawbones, I would say, there's a big land out there to tame and my horse is double-parked. I was heroic and stoic, the stereotypical male health care consumer. I paid on the way out. It took 20 years of being a cancer patient and a care giver, but I think I am on my way to becoming the stereotypical female health consumer, assertive and needy. Dr. Glenn E. Good, a psychologist at the University of Missouri, thinks my psychic sex change could add years to my life.

docs.abstract: Causes and treatment of male infertility explained (S)

headline.main: New Ways to Help Sperm Get Up and Go

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY were young, still in their 20's, when they began trying to conceive a child. When it did not happen, the New York couple decided just to keep trying, to give nature time to take its course. But nature did not oblige. When four years had passed without a pregnancy, they consulted a doctor, who quickly identified the problem: semen analysis showed that the husband had very few sperm.

docs.abstract: Brian Alexander comment confessing to writing Glamour magazine's 'Jake' column, which dispenses advice about men and their ways (S)

headline.main: Now It Can Be Told: Confessions of a Former 'Jake'

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the plane took off, the woman in the window seat flipped open her copy of the magazine. I leaned across the empty space between us. Sure enough, she was reading ''Jake,'' the column I wrote for Glamour magazine. But then, as I pondered the single best opening-line opportunity of my life, she blurted, ''This guy is such a jerk!'' I shrank away, buttoned my lip and resumed waiting patiently for my packet of mini Rold Gold pretzels.

docs.abstract: Dilemma of when and how aggressively to treat individuals at high risk for heart disease discussed; photo of Ronald and Donald Papson, twins in their 40's whose father died young of heart attack; ultrafast CT scan, new diagnostic test, found that both have abnormally high calcium buildups in blood vessels, despite young age and healthy life styles (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: RONALD PAPSON did not know the latest grim statistics about heart disease when he decided to see if he was developing it. He did not know that an average man who is 40 years old has about a 50-50 chance of developing an unmistakable sign of heart disease -- like a heart attack or chest pains -- or of suddenly dying of heart disease at some time in the future. All he knew was that his father had dropped dead of a heart attack at age 54. He and his identical twin, Donald, were only 5 at the time. Another brother was 6. But Ronald Papson, now a 46-year-old physical therapist living in Lancaster, Pa., expected that he would escape his father's fate. He had none of the classic risk factors: high cholesterol levels, smoking, diabetes. His mildly high blood pressure was controlled with medication. And he took care of himself. He and his twin had even run marathons and competed in triathlons.

docs.abstract: Relief strategies for aching backs explained (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Relief strategies for aching backs are much like cures for hiccups: what works for one person may not work for another. Here are the most common back pain treatments. * Medication: For simple muscular sprains and strains, over-the-counter medications like Nuprin, Motrin and Naprosyn often do the trick. For chronic pain, doctors may administer steroids, and in more serious cases, they may recommend epidural injections of long-acting, anti-inflammatory steroids. This treatment seems to be particularly effective for pain that radiates down the leg.

docs.abstract: Brief summary of 'seven stages' of man, from infancy to old age; photos; graph (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Men are often portrayed as big boys, differing from their younger selves only in the sums of money they spend on their toys. Indeed, because men can reproduce well into old age, and do not experience cyclical hormonal changes, their health is regarded as fairly static. But medical experts are learning that between the boy and the man stand a variety of genetic, biological and social changes. Understanding these factors may help men prepare for the stages that await them. CONSTANZA VILLALBA INFANCY

docs.abstract: Food likely eaten by the Iceman, Stone Age man whose mummified body was found in Alps in 1991, noted, as well as his poor health at time of death at about age 40 (S)

headline.main: A Last Meal For the Iceman

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE man's diet and health may not establish a cultural pattern, but it is the best archeologists have to go on for someone in the Late Stone Age. The man in question died about 5,300 years ago in the Tyrolean Alps of northern Italy. His mummified body was found in a melting glacier in 1991. The Iceman's body, the oldest known human-flesh remains, reveals a life of hardship, simple food and chronic pain.

docs.abstract: Advice on having colonoscopy, screening test that is unpleasant but has potential to practically wipe out colorectal cancer(S)

headline.main: It's No Fun, but It May Save Your Life

docs.lead_paragraph: IF scientists invented a test that could almost eliminate the third most lethal form of cancer -- and if that test was time-consuming, expensive and really, really unpleasant -- you would have the vexing situation for men regarding colon cancer. The test is the colonoscopy. This scope-type test, along with its sibling, the sigmoidoscopy, has the potential to practically wipe out colorectal cancer, which killed 27,900 men last year.
